qas.question: What is the only important factor in hunter-gatherer tool choices?
What does climate produce in hunter-gatherer societies?
What is the threat that extreme temperature causes in environment?
What does temperature impact on tool kits?
What is Torrence's 1989 theory about that ties into tool kit variability ?
What was found to be one of the many significant factors affecting hunter-gatherer tool kits?
Environments with stable temperatures posed a risk to which systems?
Risk of success is the most important factor in determining the structure of whose toolkits?
Payment structure affected the variability of which societies?
Torrence found temperature to be a significant factor for toolkits in what year?

context: <b8_0>Hunter-gatherer<b8_0/> societies manifest <a2_0>significant<a2_0/> <a1_0>variability<a1_0/>, depending on climate zone/life zone, available technology and societal structure. Archaeologists examine hunter-gatherer tool kits to measure variability across different groups. Collard et al. (<b9_0>2005<b9_0/>) found <a0_0><b5_0>temperature<b5_0/><a0_0/> to be the only statistically significant factor to impact hunter-gatherer tool kits. Using temperature as a proxy for risk, Collard et al.'s results suggest that environments with extreme temperatures pose a threat to <b6_0>hunter-gatherer<b6_0/> systems significant enough to warrant <a3_0>increased variability of tools<a3_0/>. These results support Torrence's (1989) theory that <a4_0>risk of failure<a4_0/> is indeed the most important factor in determining the structure of <b7_0>hunter-gatherer<b7_0/> toolkits.
